headline.main: EVEN FOR THE PURIST, PASSOVER CAN BE GOURMET'S DELIGHT

byline.original: By HELEN NASH; Helen Nash is the author of ''Kosher Cuisine'' (Random House, 1984)

docs.lead_paragraph: PASSOVER is the Jewish holiday most closely associated with food. It starts with a specially prepared meal, the seder, many of whose elements symbolize the Jews' captivity in Egypt and subsequent release. For the eight days of Passover, leavened foods are forbidden but it is not, as many think, a time of limited food choices monotonously repeated. Even for a purist, Passover can be a gourmet delight. The seders, served on the first two nights of the holiday, which this year starts next Wednesday evening, are ritual meals that should consist of traditional required dishes. In the days that follow, however, great variety is possible at every meal. April offers an abundance of seasonal fruits, produce, fish and nuts, all of which may be used.

docs.abstract: Barbara Santich travel article reviews restaurants in Canberra, Australia: Juniperberry, Atlantic, Chairman and Yip and Ottoman Cuisine; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, the capital and seat of Australia's Federal Government since 1927, is a showcase city. A totally planned urban entity -- even the central lake is man-made -- it is home to the National Library, the National Archives, the National Gallery, the newly opened National Portrait Gallery, the National Botanic Gardens and the National Museum of Australia. Canberra is spacious, densely green, a garden city ringed by hills, with the clean-cut profiles of the Tidbinbilla and Brindabella Mountain Ranges to the west. Its broad thoroughfares are lined with eucalyptus and deciduous trees, which in autumn (March through May) glow with color. In spring (September to November), there are pale pink blossoms and vivid tulips everywhere.

headline.seo: A Review of Han Asian Cuisine in Granby

docs.abstract: Rand Richards Cooper reviews Han Asian Cuisine in Granby (Metropolitan/Connecticut).
docs.lead_paragraph: The big menu at Han Asian Cuisine in Granby, created by the chef and primary owner, James Chen, combines three cuisines, Japanese, Chinese and Thai — with a few Korean add-ons.
